div.p: Structural properties of the antiferromagnetic insulators CuFeO 2 and NaFeO 2 were studied by synchrotron x-ray diffraction to 50 and 35 GPa, respectively, using diamond anvil cells.

Pressures were generated with the TAU oposite/plate diamond anvil cells having anvils with 300-µm diam. culets. Argon was used as a pressurizing medium. Angle-dispersive mode high-pressure XRD studies were performed at the ID09A beam-line, diffraction images were collected with a MAR345 detector. The image data were integrated using the FIT2D program [1], and the resulting diffraction patterns were analyzed with the GSAS [2] program. Pressure was measured using the ruby fluorescence technique and Au or Pt XRD markers.

The case of Cu-Fe Delafossite. Cuprous ferrite (CuFeO2) has the hexagonal layered structure _ 3 R m which consists of hexagonal layers of Cu 1+ , O 2-, and Fe 3+ (see Fig 1 ); the antiferromagnetic Fe 3+ (S=5/2) layers are separated by nonmagnetic layers of Cu 1+ (S=0) and O [3]. At ambient pressure spins are highly frustrated between neighboring layers as well as within layers but at ~18 GPa CuFeO2 becomes a normal antiferromagnet [4]. Recent High Pressure (HP) 57 Fe Mössbauer studies [5] detected the onset of Fe 2+ species at around 23 GPa. The Fe 3+ L Fe 2+ process has been attributed to Cu-Fe band overlap resulting in the Cu 1+ -Cu 2+ counter process. X-ray diffraction studies showed that the low pressure (LP) structure is stable up to ~ 16 GPa and that in agreament with Zhao et al. [6] the a-axis is approximately four times more compressible than the caxis (Fig. 2). This is undoubtedly a unique case of an ambient pressure highly According to preliminary data analysis the HP phase has similar to LP phase hexagonal Fe 3+ 0 2 4 6 8 10 12 14 16 5.64 5.66 5.68 5.70 5.72 5.74 5.76 5.78 5.80 CuFeO 2 Our data Zhao et. al c/a Pressure [GPa] Fig. 2. Pressure dependence of c/a ratio for CuFeO 2 . layered structure but in contrast to the _ 3 R m space group, it accommodates two different types of Fe and Cu sites where 1/3 of the Fe layers are occupied by Fe 2+ . Unfortunately strong peak broadening accompanying these transitions does not allow precise structural identification. The Na-Fe delafossite. Whereas the Cu 1+ -Fe 3+ PI band overlap may result in the formation of paramagnetic Cu 2+ ; this will not be the case with alkali ions. Our studies of NaFeO2 ( _ 32 / R m space group) have shown an isostructural transition at P~11 GPa accompanied by significant alteration of the oxygen positional parameter value, c/a parameters ratio (Fig. 4), and increase of bulk modulus value. The Fe-O bond length show substantial increase corroborating with a reduction of Na-O bond length.

This result is rather unexpected taking into account the allowed valence states of Na. Further carefull studies of the effect of replacing monovalent Cu with Na, Ag and Li extended to higher pressures are desirable taking into account our results obtained for NaFeO 2 .

figure.figDesc: .e., (c/a) P 0 d d > . With further pressure increase two appreciable structural transformations (Fig. 3) are detected corroborating with: (i) transition to a normal antiferromagnet at ~ 18 GPa, and (ii) valence transformation at ~ 23 GPa. These PI transitions are reversible in pressure.
